result.execSummary:
The defendant Joe B. Haehnlein was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Unlawful Phone Use-Threaten w/ Obscenity, a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.012(1)(b).
  • Bail Jumping-Felony, a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(b).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes:
Pay costs and DNA surcharges. If probation is discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil Judgment will be entered against the Defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due. All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt. Per Wisconsin Statute, funds from prison accounts may be used for obligations in accordance with prison policy not to exceed 25% of gross.
(Added DNA Surcharge was missed on Count 3)

May be transferred to Waupaca County.
Be assessed for mental health and comply with any recommendations as directed by agent.
Seek and maintain full time employment.
Follow with other counseling as recommended by the agent.
No contact personally/telephone/mail with Jennifer Seefelt.
No contact personally/telephone/mail with Judge Flugaur other than ordinary court appearances currently or in the future.

From DOC request to correct record. /s/RS: granted
Vacate Sentencing After Revocation on Count 3 as probation was discharged on 11-17-2016.

Defendant Joe B. Haehnlein in court with Attorney (Atty) Richard E. Bender. Defendant Joe B. Haehnlein in custody. Prosecuting Assistant District Attorney (ADA) Kristina Mukoski appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Cases heard at this time are 15CF-288 and 17CM-318.

2:07 PM Court calls cases.
Atty Mukoski states appearances.
Field Supervisor is also present.

Counsel received the same revocation order and warrant and summary with the addendum court memo dated December 6th.
Atty Bender received the December 6th letter.

Court questions Field Supervisor regarding the basis for the Department's initial recommendation seeking prison time and the Department's subsequent recommendation of six to nine months. 
Field Supervisor is not familiar with this case, neither is any of the other agents in the office.  Previous agent retired. Field Supervisor cannot answer this question.
Filed Supervisor take a moment to read the letter. Court explains the letter, for the record.
Discussions continue.

Atty Bender addresses the Court, regarding the change to the recommendation, his client was of the impression that the sentence would be time served. Defendant has been in Waupaca Jail for 250 day.

Atty Mukoski addresses the Court prior to sentencing, makes recommendations.
Atty Bender addresses the Court prior to sentencing, this is a joint recommendation. Defendant's mother is present. Defendant has three children, all under the age of seven.
Defendant addresses the Court prior to sentencing.

Court has a number of factors to consider to determine sentencing.

15CF-288:
Count 3: (unlawful phone use) (Vacated Sentencing After Revocation on Count 3 only as was discharged from probation on 11-17-16 /s/RS 01-07-2018).
90 days jail
250 days jail credit
Time served
All outstanding costs/assessments to be converted to a civil judgment

Count 4: (felony bailjumping)
6 months jail concurrent to Count 3
250 days jail credit
Time served
All outstanding costs/assessments to be converted to a civil judgment

17CM-318:
Count 2:
90 days jail concurrent to 15CF-288
250 days jail credit
Time served
All outstanding costs/assessments to be converted to a civil judgment

records.addlTxt:
Defendant Joe B. Haehnlein in court with attorney Jerod Barkley. Defendant Joe B. Haehnlein in custody. David R. Knaapen appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
3:07 p.m.  Court calls the case. 

Atty Barkley makes statements to the Court.  It was his understanding that they would be prepared to go to sentencing today with time served on conditional time, which may now not be the case. 
Atty Knaapen makes statements to the Court.  

3:11 p.m.  Court will take a brief recess and would like to see counsel in chambers. 

***Clerk is now A.Z.***

3:26 PM Court is back in session.

There is a plea agreement.
Defendant will be pleading to Count 3 as charged in amended information and as to Count 4 in amended information.
Counts 1, 2, and 5 would be dismissed and read in.

Defense is free to argue any of the conditions.

Plea questionnaire/Agreement filed.

Defendant enters a plea of: NO CONTEST Count 3
Defendant enters a plea of: NO CONTEST Count 4

Defendant has had a chance to review the amended information.
Court questions Defendant regarding pleas.
Court informs Defendant of Constitutional Rights. Court advises Defendant of Elements State must prove for the Charge.
Court questions Attorney Barkely for Defendant.
Court finds Defendant's Plea is freely, voluntarily and intelligently made.
Attorneys stipulate that there is factual basis for the charges.

BY THE COURT:
Court finds a sufficient factual basis to support the charges.
Court finds the defendant guilty.  Clerk directed to enter Judgment of Conviction this date.
Count 1: Dismissed and Read In
Count 2: Dismissed and Read In
Count 3: Guilty
Count 4: Guilty
Count 5: Dismissed and Read In

Atty Knaapen makes sentencing arguments to the Court. State did contact victims in this case and were aware of recommendations and were in agreement.
Atty Barkley makes sentencing arguments to the Court, requests transfer of probation to Waupaca County.
Defendant addresses the Court prior to sentencing.

Court addresses the parties.

BY THE COURT:
Count 3:
Sentence is Withheld
Probation for a period of 12 Months, concurrent to Count 4
May be transferred to Waupaca County
Conditions:
Be assessed for mental health and comply with any recommendations as directed by agent
Seek and maintain full time employment
Follow with other counseling as recommended by the agent
No contact personally/telephone/mail with Jennifer Seefelt
No contact personally/telephone/mail with Judge Flugaur other than ordinary court appearances currently or in the future
Pay court costs
Pay DNA surcharge

Count 4:
Sentence is Withheld
Probation for a period of 36 Months
May be transferred to Waupaca County
Conditions:
Jail sentence for a period of 150 Days
Jail credit of 129 Days
Remaining time to be served immediately, starting today
Huber is granted
Comply with conditions of probation as stated in Count 3
Pay court costs
Pay DNA surcharge

Defendant states he has job prospects in Waupaca.
Court addresses rights/penalites.
Appeal rights are addressed. CR-233 to be filed before leaving today.

Atty Barkley moves to withdraw motion to amend bond.

BY THE COURT:
Motion is withdrawn.
for Reduction of Bail

NOT GUILTY Plea(s) entered.

BY THE COURT: If he can arrange inpatient treatment, bond will be modified.  At which time he is to return to the jail, at that point, bond modification will be looked at.

Defendant Joe B. Haehnlein in court with attorney Jerod Barkley. Defendant Joe B. Haehnlein in custody. David R. Knaapen appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Atty Knaapen makes statements re: bond. 
Atty Barkley concurs. 

Defendant waives right to preliminary hearing. 
Court questions defendant regarding waiver of preliminary hearing. 
Court questions Attorney.
Court finds the defendant has freely, voluntarily and intelligently waived the preliminary hearing. 
On the defendants waiver of the preliminary hearing, Court determines, based on the facts contained in the complaint, there is sufficient probable cause and binds the defendant over for trial.  Pre-trial conference scheduled for August 31, 2015 at 11:00 am.
for Reduction of Bail

State recommends an additional bond condition.
